utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Morgan Ortagus, Marie -- excuse me -- Marie Harf, Lawrence Jones, and Tom Shillue. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and felling a little better, and this is The Five. 2020 Democratic frontrunner, Joe Biden, reportedly feeling burned by his former boss according to Vanity Fair. The former V.P. is upset over Barack Obama meeting with other potential 2020 contenders like Beto O'Rourke before he's officially made his decision. A Biden spokesperson pushing back against the story calling it unequivocally false. Biden may have some other obstacles in his way, a new poll showing 59 percent of Democratic and independent voters are excited for someone entirely new to run for president. Biden comes in second followed by Bernie Sanders and Beto O'Rourke. And 70 percent of those same voters say Hillary Clinton should not run again. President Trump going after Democrats as we have more of that? No, we don't. Is that just a poll? OK. Well, the teleprompter is working very well today. Marie Harf, now that you're here. I don't think -- even if Biden were upset, I don't think he would say so because it's just obvious that Obama is going to have to meet with lots of Democrats before 2020, right?

utterances.speaker: MARIE HARF, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I actually don't think -- I mean, Joe Biden is an adult, right? He's been in politics a long time. He and Barack Obama are very close. I don't think he's probably very upset about this. It's interesting though in that poll, 59 percent want someone new. I think that we see that in both parties, right? That's how we got Donald Trump. But Joe Biden was at 53 percent. So, Joe Biden knows that he's very popular in the party, he's popular among independents, and Barack Obama is going to have to meet with lots of people. I do think you will see President Obama trying to keep his powder dry a little bit and not really wait into what will be what? Twenty five, thirty people in Democratic primary here? But if Joe Biden wants to run, Joe Biden will have a lot of support among people like Barack Obama, even if he doesn't endorse him, he was his vice president for 8 years. I don't think he's mad about Beto getting a meeting, like he has thicker skin than that.

utterances.speaker: LAWRENCE JONES, HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But he was his vice president the last election as well, and we know that the party leadership as well as the president all did the garden meetings saying that, you know, he wasn't going to run. And this was all because Hillary Clinton was the chosen candidate.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's not why Biden didn't run.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And so, I do think -- I do think that there is -- he will be frustrated if the president doesn't get behind him. Of course, he's a -- he understands that the president -- he's a former president, has to meet with all the candidates. But the former vice president is going to be expecting President Obama to get behind him because he did step aside and let Hillary Clinton run.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not easy to tell somebody that maybe it's not -- it's past their time, right? It's not easy to tell someone that. We're not elephants.

utterances.speaker: TOM SHILLUE, HOST
utterances.utterance: It's -- you know, you see the word cult of (ph) the person -- or the phrase cult of (ph) personality about the Republicans that the Republican Party is now a cult of (ph) personality and it's all about Donald Trump. I think it is -- that is not true. The cult of (ph) personality is the Democrat Party. The cult is Donald Trump, but they're an anti-Trump party and that's all they are at this point. That's why they need a new personality. They're desperately in search of a personality because they think that Trump is all about personality, he's not. It's really about policy. They liked his policies, not his personality. They didn't want just someone new, Marie, they wanted Donald Trump. It wasn't anyone new. And so, they are searching for -- that's why Beto is such a big thing because they're not really sure about, you know, why they like him but they think he's a personality that can take on Trump. That's all they want.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They want -- they just want someone who's got all spark, Morgan.

utterances.speaker: MORGAN ORTAGUS, HOST
utterances.utterance: Maybe. You know, I'm really looking forward to this primary because it's someone new.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Me too.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Who is in the Republican primary, it was vicious and awful. And this looks like the Republican primary times like a thousand, like, just get out the popcorn. I can't wait. What's ironic to me is how the Dem activist base is sort of freaking out with the top three people in polling are all white men. We've seen a lot of people that have a problem with that. And the Republican Party has been criticized nonstop by Democrats for being the party of white men. And anytime you oppose the policy of President Barack Obama it must have been because you're a racist. And now the women in the minority that are going to be running for president are going to be turning that around on their fellow Democrats. It will be interesting for me to see how Bernie, how Biden, how O'Rourke answer that white male charge which is like almost worse than being a criminal in the Democrat Party right now.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I think what's interesting -- what frustrates me about fellow Democrats is they're looking for a savior right now.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But they're looking -- and that's why they look at Beto because they just want someone who's the perfect candidate and a perfect package.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But they had one in Barack Obama.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Exactly. And he won twice, overwhelmingly, in one state like Indiana, right? The Democrats need to compete in. But I keep telling my fellow Democrats we don't need a savior. The primary process sometimes works itself out. It sometimes puts forward a candidate that can win in a general. The Republican primary was insane. It put forth a candidate that could win a general election, same with Barack Obama in 2008. Sometimes these processes actually work --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do have a question for you, Marie, tell me just about, like, logistically how you think things will change when California moves earlier for their primary because there are so many delegates then? Does that change a lot?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That will change it. Also the fact that super delegates, these parties elders who are given a lot of power in previous Democratic primary nominating processes, they helped anoint Hillary Clinton, for example, they have much less power now. So the power has been pushed down to the grassroots activists. Democrats in Iowa are different than Democrats in New Hampshire and South Carolina. Nevada now no longer a caucus, now a primary. These things seem very wonky, but they actually matter when there's going to be a very hotly contested primary. That's why you're going to see candidates go to Iowa, go to New Hampshire. You already are. This primary is starting like now.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: The generational struggle in the Democrat Party is sort of a fascinating one as well because the Dem -- in a presidential election, they rely so much on those younger voters that didn't show out for Hillary Clinton, especially younger women. And the generational struggle just isn't about their 2020 nominee. It's look at the angst that was geared towards Pelosi and to Schumer, people who are in their 70's and have been in leadership for a long time. And I think you're sort of seeing the base of the Democrat Party, especially the young people say, you know, it's our turn to lead. It's our time for leadership.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Well, one part of the Democrats -- problem they're going to have is that authentic leadership because there's a lot of candidates that weren't as far left when they were in other offices, when it came to Beto --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Kirsten Gillibrand.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He voted for legislation to essentially dismantle Obamacare. He's been --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's why Bernie has been attacking him.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Exactly. Because a lot -- and Kamala Harris, she's all of a sudden for criminal justice reform, she didn't govern that way when she was attorney general of California. And so, as it's get heated -- and let's be clear, Biden is an experienced politician. He is not going to play fair with them. He's got to go after every single thing that they did --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I'm ready.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- and that's when you're going to see that experienced leader. That why I've said, right now, when it comes to the Democrats, he's the only candidate that has a shot in the running because he has been that consistent leader.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, what do you think about that, Tom?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: What's your poll numbers, Tom, from this time in 2015, or '11, or '07, we would be talking about a whole different group of people.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And all the numbers have to do with Trump, that's the whole thing. Even 70 percent don't want her to run, they're mad at her because she lost to Trump. Like, that's why her numbers are so low.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Like, don't show your face around here again.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes. And I think they will forgive -- policy, none of it matters anymore. They will forgive Beto --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I don't think so.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: If they think he has the -- I don't think they're right --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Even the Bernie Sanders' people are not like solid Bernie people right now, right? They're sort of saying you're going to have to court us a little bit.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Well -- and to Morgan's point it's a good one. There will be a debate in the party about people saying, look, we just need to win. And someone like Joe Biden or Beto, they can win versus this, but we need to win with a fill in the blank, woman, minority, progressive, whatever that blank is, and you're going to have Democrats who say job number one is to win. And we need to figure out how to do that and take care of the rest later --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: You know what's interesting --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: -- quite frankly.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- in the poll that we're all looking at earlier, actually, 41 percent of Democrats thought that Bernie should not run again. And so, for me, when you see Bernie --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Amen.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- you see Hillary, I'm sort of -- well, first of all, he's not even a Democrat. It's sort of weird.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: He's not a Democrat.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: But, you know, for me, instead of trying to Tonya Harding, you know, Beto already in the process --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Good reference.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Thank you. I Googled that. I remember her name earlier today. But why isn't Bernie sort of saying, you know, I set forth this more liberal agenda for the party, and I'm going to help bring up people like AOC, and Beto, and others, and bring up the next generation. But because it's not really about that, it's about he's selfish. It's about power. More than it's about ideology. They're all so power hungry Å¸_"

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But they have --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- it can't even lead a movement and step aside and let someone else --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I disagree in a way because that new movement -- that is where the energy is --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Part of it, yeah.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Not all of it, part of it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: So, there was a time -- even people on the right, and I've said this yesterday on The Five, that we will laugh at Ocasio-Cortez, but they're winning. And it's not just her that's winning, there are incremental changes that they want to make. And I think that the Democrats have to take them -- they are the freedom caucus of the left.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But they're only winning in certain places. And the way we took back the majority in the House is by winning moderate seats in Kansas City, and Savannah, and Detroit, and Denver. All of these places -- we took back the House with moderates. A lot of the attention goes to progressives, and that's the fight you're going to have --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We've got to run, guys. Do you have any last thoughts, Tom?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Biden, 2020? SHILLUE: I agree it's going to be fun. We'll see what happens.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, we will see. That's my favorite show (ph). President Trump going after Democrats as the partial government shutdown hits day six. See it next.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: President Trump trying to pin blame on Democrats as the partial government shutdown enters day six, the president accusing Democrats of obstruction and hypocrisy when it comes to the border wall.

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.utterance: We're going to have a wall. We're going to have safety. We need safety for our country even from this standpoint. We need a wall. So when you say how long is it going to take? When are they going to say that we need border security? When are the Democrats going to say? Don't forget, the Democrats all agreed that you need a wall until I wanted it. Once I wanted it, they didn't agree.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: With negotiations reportedly at a standstill, House Republicans are saying members shouldn't expect any new vote this week. OK. Dana, I want to start with some of the human impact of this because we now know hundreds of thousands of federal workers having to work without getting paid, you and I both been federal government employees as has Morgan, there are real people who are impacted by this.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right. So -- however, I do think that this could go on for a very long time. Mark Meadows, a congressman for North Carolina, head of the freedom caucus, was on -- with CNN, and Dana Bash, earlier, and saying that he talked President Trump, and this could go on for a long time. And, in fact, I have a theory.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it could go on until the State of the Union.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That usually happens towards the end of the month. Remember yesterday in Iraq when President Trump made a secret trip over there that we're going to talk about later on the show. One of the things he said in the Q&A with a reporter is that he plans to go see the border. And that he was going to go see the border and take the press with him, and he said I think I'm going to go right before the State of the Union. And I think that it could go on that long because the president is going to dig in his heels. And I'm not saying -- I don't know anything. This is purely my thought process. But I'm just thinking if it goes to next week, right, and Nancy Pelosi then, presumably, she becomes the Speaker of the House, then you're at January 6th, OK? So then January 27th, 28th, whenever the State of the Union is, I could see it lasting that long.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: So, Lawrence --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I think it's longer than that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Yeah. We have no choice.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Let me ask you a practical question, Nancy Pelosi when she takes over and the House Democrats are in charge, they will have the votes to pass a clean funding bill. It very well may pass the Senate as well, even despite Republicans picking up more votes. If President Trump vetoes that, is that a good idea? Do you think that's what he will do? That seems like a bigger political gamble.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He doesn't have any choice. If he doesn't deliver --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- on this piece of his promises from the last campaign, he doesn't win 2020, period. That the only reason why -- the president was prepared to cave last week. There was multiple reports of it. He was bringing everybody in. And the moment everyone started attacking him and his base, it was the first time I ever seen the president fearful because all there is loyal supporters. And so, the president realizes this is the gamble right now. Either this is the last time he can get it passed, and so he has to hold a firm stance on this or he won't get reelected.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I disagree, but I'll let everybody talk and then I'll take it on. HARF: Well, Tom, his poll numbers have already started to go down a little bit. And the promise, to be fair, during the campaign was that not the taxpayers would pay for it, but Mexico would pay for it. What's your take on this?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Mexico -- you know, Democrats saying, well, we'll wait for Mexico to pay for it. That's a loser argument.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But he said it. He did say it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He did say it.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: What? It doesn't matter. The base didn't believe it anyway. They knew he was going to get the money other ways.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Sure, it's true.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Listen, when I do my talk radio, you know, the callers come in, they all say, look, we knew he was going to find other ways for Mexico to pay for it. We knew he had the NAFTA thing. They want construction to start on the wall. He's right. What he just said, that clip we played, he said Democrats already voted for this. They said they wanted -- they want a border barrier, right? Remember, it was in 2006, Democrats did vote. Obama did vote. The Schumer, I believe, voted for the fencing. That's why the president is changing, he's saying, look, I'll take if they want to call it fencing, if they want to call it steel slats --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He just wants it.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes. And he's right, that clip he showed that's perfect logic. They voted for it until Trump wanted it, and then they didn't. That's very true.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Here's what's going to happen, January 3rd, Nancy Pelosi will take over as Speaker of the House. The House will pass a clean C.R. bill, right? And that's without the wall funding they will submit to the Senate. That will not past the 60 vote threshold --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You don't think so?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: No. But here is what I will think will happen, is that you will start to see moderate senators, especially in states like Maine, people that have a re-election that might be a Republican Senate in a state where the president isn't popular, they might be able to start to pick them off. I don't think they'll be able to pick them off to get to 60. So, if I'm the president or his team and I'm looking at this from a strategic perspective, it feels like we're on defense. And what we need to do is get back on to offense. How do we do that? We need to put things on the table that the Democrats can't turn down. Just saying I'm going to keep the government closed until you give me the wall funding is not going to win --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Like DACA?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Like DACA. Like TPS renewal. Like the BRIDGE Act.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: There's a number --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He was tweeting about DACA.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: -- immigration related, but there's a number of things that we could put on the table that would start to break apart there -- right now their coalition is united. I worry the longer this drags on that we start to get moderate senators defecting, going to the Democrat side, so that's why we need to go on offense.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I disagree with that because -- I mean, from a practical standpoint, I get it -- ORTAGUS: What are you going to get the House to pass?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: To try to -- you know, get some type of compromise. But there's two separate issues when it comes to securing the border, and then the citizens that are non-citizens that came here no fault of their own, being here illegally. And so --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I agree. You're arguing policy, I'm arguing tactics.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: All I'm saying, they tried it before and it didn't get done. The president offered how many people, 1.8?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: And they still turned it down. So, they've tried that tactic before. They didn't get it passed. So, it's going to go either the wall or nothing. And the president is going to take that hard line.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Dana?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. So, two things, so one on the communications standpoint. So the president and the Democrats are in impasse, so how do you break an impasse? He is the one that holds the bully pulpit, so he's the one can do something different. And I think he needs to show, not tell, or show not tweet. So, I would let other people do the talking for me. So he has great people at the customs and border patrol who are civil servants, take them down with the press and let them show them their situation, show them how it would be more effective if they had border fencing, wall, whatever you want to call it, in these areas. How it would actually save money in the long run because you wouldn't need four people in one area, you just need one person in an area when you have that thing. So, showing not telling I think would be really important. But I also feel like the president has a lot to point to aside from this $5 billion for the wall funding that he has done on immigration that he could take to the base and say, do you want to know what I've done? Here's all these things, asylum claims. Basically getting Mexico to hold asylum seekers rather than being held in the United States, that's such a big deal --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: It is a big deal, yeah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And he's not getting enough credit for that. And Kirstjen Nielsen organized that Mexicans are basically saying, OK, we'll swallow that, we have to do it. We've already had that same agreement with Canada. He's done more on workplace enforcement. He's done more to get troops to the border. He's shown he's willing to do that. The visa overstay, which is the really big issue, nobody is talking about that, and he could do that. So, I feel like there are things that he could do that he could talk, then say, like, in addition to all these other things that we want to do with border security, I've done all of these things as well. He's willing to fight all the way up to the Supreme Court for it. He's got a story to tell. I think he gets himself too boxed in just talking about the wall.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Right. But it plays with the base line, he's right (ph) about that. We will keep monitoring to see how long the shutdown continues. In the meantime, just how addicted are Americans to their phones? We all have them out on the table here. Now there's a new way to kick that habit, those details up next.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Some people are so addicted to technology and their devices they're now turning to rehab much like programs helping with drug and alcohol problems, tech addicts are now turning to secluded detox facilities that include 12-step programs and intense therapy. They're also agreeing to use their smart phones with limits and monitoring systems. And so, Tom, one of the things that I thought was interesting and when we were reading about this and how people were addicted to their smart phones is that graying Gen X-ers are the ones who are the most addictive to their phones. So as a graying Gen X-ers --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, grain? What's it? Graying?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Graying. Like gray hair.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Graying. Oh, how rude. SHILLUE: Grain Gen X-ers, yes. Well, look --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: It is true, we got a little obsessed. And when, you know, I was a real tech advocate in the 90s, and I loved when the iPhones came out, and I did get obsessed with it, and I think we suffered from it. I think, because -- I don't know, it really took over our lives in a way that with younger people it's just -- it hasn't taken over their lives as much.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: You see, I was surprised that Gen X-ers used the phone more than millennials.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it's clear why. We have to do -- our work is there, that we're in the prime of our working lives. We want to keep in touch with our parents as they get older. And for those of us that have children, you want to keep in touch with your children. So, it's like, if you're working -- if you're trying to find a work-life balance like the most effective tool is your phone.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Yes, you're right. We have more -- we need to talk to more people. You're so right.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's a good excuse. This is what it is, you guys aren't used to it. You guys aren't used to it so you all got a little taste of it and you can't put it down. My generation grew up with it, and so it's nothing to us.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's not fancy.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: We don't even use it that much because it's like -- it's always a new toy. So we just put it down and move on to the next thing. Whereas, you guys -- you guys get loyal to it -- yes, it is. It's just like a phone, we grew up with computers and all that stuff.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: The millennial end of the table is irritating --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I do think there's an addictive quality to it. And I like how the new iPhone -- you can monitor your screen time.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And I like the fact that people are now doing phone-free holidays and dinners. I really -- I like that because you can get -- and it has not just mental but physical. And my doctor told me the more you look down at your phone your hands and your wrist and your neck and everything like, it changes --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It creates a wrinkle.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. That happens if the wrinkle thing is a problem.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I got the wrist thing on election night for the rest of that week.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And it also encourages -- I mean, the mental aspect of it --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Wrinkles thumb.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: -- fear of missing out, like you've always -- people lives look so air brushed and perfect on-line. And there're all these studies about how kids or adults who see people's lives they get depressed because they don't think their life is as good.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I've never had that problem.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I don't know how to answer that.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I don't get jealous. I'm happy for their success.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But there are studies, especially, teenagers, you know, there are down sides to it. And I think having some balance --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Huge downside.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: -- is very good.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I mean, need to go further. It's not just balance. I mean, people need to put their phones away. I wake up -- I used to wake and go to the phone and read the news because I said I work in the news business. I need to keep up with the headlines. Now, I don't. I keep the phone away. I make my coffee, I sit there, I read text. My life is better. It's like -- it's insane. But you don't need -- you can do it by yourself. You don't need rehab. It's just somebody trying to get you to pay for their -- it's a paid vacation because then they can submit it, and so it's a medical issue.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: So there's something called selfie wrist, and Fox News is reporting on this. This is intense Fox News reporting this Christmas week. But selfie wrist is like, I guess, when you take your phone and take a selfie, you're holding it for too long, you can get pain in your wrist. I love selfies. Do you have a selfie wrist issues?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No. I have long arms, so it's just like -- it's just a little click. But what concerns me about all this tech nonsense is that because people can have personal responsibility they want the government to come in and regulate these tech companies --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: All right, libertarian.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- and the technology. Just because you can't have self-control doesn't mean that the government needs to come and be your daddy.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: If you don't like the way that Facebook is selling your private information, if you don't like you're addicted, they've built these platforms to be addictive. Guess what? They built fast food to be addictive so you can go to McDonald's and all these others. You should be responsible (ph) -- delete the app. Instead, they're too lazy and they want Congress to investigate these people and say, yeah, yeah, yeah, it's addictive and they're selling this. You signed up for it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But sometimes they don't tell you what they're selling. There's difference between like their -- your info --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Terms of service.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: No, but -- Facebook has not always been honest.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Delete it --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: They have a story on the BBC about eye yoga that people are going to because their eyes have become so pained and damaged because it's staring at screens.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And they -- I don't know if it works.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Eye yoga is the same people that are doing the dumb rehab. Just put the phone down, dummy. HARF: I actually agree with that.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I have fantastic selfie collection because I like meet -- when I meet world leaders, or really important people, or famous people, I like to ask them for selfies because --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: You're that girl.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I think it's really funny. My husband is always like, yeah, if I asked them for a selfie they would be like go away. Please go away. But I have a good collection of it, so I don't have selfie wrist, I just have a bruise on my wrist --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: You need a selfie stick.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I don't know if --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I don't know if it's the selfies that are causing the strain. It's that they're texting too much.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: No, it's called selfie wrist.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Fake!

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: FOXNews.com.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Oh, it's Fox News? Then it may be right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Well, now that we've settled that. I think holidays without -- particularly this holiday week. Holidays without the phone. You don't need to document every part of your Christmas.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: My family did that. We decided that we're just going to enjoy each other.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And wasn't it better?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: It was way better.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I get bored. All right.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Come on.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Everybody take a selfie in the commercial break. Some media criticism over President Trump's surprise visit to troops in Iraq reaches epic levels. You won't believe what they are saying now, or maybe you will.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Before President Trump's surprise trip to Iraq, the media constantly attacked him for not visiting the troops. So you'd think they'd be happy to see President Trump in a combat zone, right? But they weren't. Not so fast. Check out the latest case of the media's whiplash.

utterances.speaker: JIM ACOSTA, CNN CHIEF WHITE HOUSE CORRESPONDENT
utterances.utterance: We saw the president signing a campaign hat, a red hat, his Make America Great Again hat.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.utterance: The president seems to have confused, in some way, this troop deploy -- this troop visit with a campaign rally.

utterances.speaker: REAR ADMIRAL JOHN KIRBY, CNN MILITARY AND DIPLOMATIC ANALYST
utterances.utterance: Every time he's around military audiences, he tends to politicize it.

utterances.speaker: DON LEMON, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.utterance: When we turned on CNN and we saw the president politicizing a Christmas message, it was like he kept saying -- he's like the Grinch.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Mr. Trump, once again, used a captive audience of American heroes to push his unpopular domestic agenda. This time the wall.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: The media is the Grinch. Morgan, there's two things that I don't like.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: One, I don't like presidents that go overseas and apologize for our country. And I also don't like when presidents are overseas, and the media criticizes the president while he's trying to do things for our troops. What's your take?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, I spent a holiday in 2007, I was in Baghdad. I wasn't on military deployment. I was on civilian mobilization at that time with USAID. And it's tough when you are overseas when you're spending Thanksgiving and Christmas. And I think any time you're there and a president, any president of any party, comes over, you are so excited, because you're working. You're in the trenches. You're away from your family. You're away from your friends. So I think it's great that the president went. And I just want to say, you know, for the people that don't understand the military's excitement, many of the members, to see the president, they feel that way for this president. They feel that way for any president coming over. Because they serve, we all serve at the pleasure of the commander in chief. So, I don't really understand this collective freak-out about people being excited to see the president. They should be. Let's give him a break.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Well, but to be fair, some of that criticism is overblown. But there are legitimate criticisms of some of the things President Trump said. He lied to them and told them they hadn't gotten a pay raise until he gave them one. That's not true. He told them it was 10 percent. That's not true. He also waded into some domestic political issues like the wall, which to many people seems a little bit inappropriate. So I think it's very good that he went. And I think some media criticism is too far. But it is OK - -

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But they loved it, Marie. Did you see those military men and women there?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: They were excited.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Had MAGA hats, T-shirts, flags.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But it's also fair to point out that the president told them things that were not accurate about their pay raises. That is not unfair media criticism.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I think that's totally --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: That is fact-checking a president.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I totally agree with you, Marie. But the bulk of the criticism was the formality of what the president did. That they didn't believe that they should have had the hats. Those military men and women looked like they were having a good time, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Absolutely. And they should. And they deserve to have one. I just feel like -- one, about the wall, the president sees that as national security.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So he doesn't see that as a domestic issue.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But he attacked Democrats.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, that's something --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: In other words, he behaved exactly as he always does. No change.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But that doesn't make it OK. It doesn't make it right.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: When are people going to stop being surprised, though? I mean, to me, it's "Look at the way he behaved in an unprecedented fashion." But I mean, that's the way he always behaves. Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And a trip like that is -- it's hard to plan. It was an important one to do. And also, if you are somebody who was concerned about the president's seemingly abrupt decision just to say, "OK, we're pulling out of Syria," well, the other thing you got yesterday is to find out he has no plans to take troops out of Iraq, and he thinks that we can stage attacks from Iraq if we need to. So, that would -- that should be a good things.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: You know, that's amazing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: If you don't like the way he delivered it, that's OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I want to hone into that, because there was some news in the president when he was talking about what actually happened and how he got to this decision. He talked about that he had told the generals --

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Are you talking about Syria?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: OK.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: He talked to the generals, and he said, "Hey, you've got six months to come do this." They came back to the president and said, "We need more time." Then they came to him a second time, "Need more time." And that third time he decided that "No, guys. We've set a deadline." Do you think the president set this deadline because of the campaign promise, and he should have listened to the generals a little bit more? Or do you think the president is right on this?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think what we're going through right now is a transition in our national security. And so the president's team, his first year in office laid out something called the national security strategy. And that is how does the president see the world? Marie has probably been a part of drafting these in the Obama administration. And in that national security strategy, the president shifted us to great power conflict with Russia, with China, a focus on that. So the president is trying to shift us from a Middle East-focused strategy. Admittedly, the Obama administration also wanted to focus us towards Asia. And so what happens is when you're shifting, that means military equipment is different. That means fighting is different. So we're in the middle of the transition of the forces, and that is sometimes rocky.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: But do you agree -- do you agree. I can't -- I mean, you're so focused on countries like Iran and their power in the region. We've talked about this.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Do you agree with just abruptly pulling out and letting Iran fill that vacuum?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: I do not. But I also think that what has been communicated over the last week seems that the president is -- is starting to slow down that decision. That it's not happening overnight. I think the president's team put out a fantastic strategy to counter Iran. You can't counter Iran if you're not in the region. It's impossible. And so perhaps, you know, you're saying, "I don't understand to counter Iran anymore," or "I want to focus on ISIS." It's done. Moving on. I think the American people just need to understand what the strategy is, because we have a greater strategy. If we're going to actually counter them, we have to be in the region. That doesn't necessarily mean in Syria. But listen, I could nerd out and spend another hour with Marie going over this stuff. She's got a lot of experience here, too.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Tom, as Dana corrected noted, the president said that that's why he's leaving people in Iraq as well, too. So they could rush there if there is any type of conflict where he feels like any type of terrorist organization is gaining more ground. But do you think that's the correct strategy?

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, it may be. That's what I have been saying on the radio all week. That I don't know if I -- if I would agree with Trump's strategy or Mad Dog Mattis's strategy. But I don't think it's unprecedented. You know, president -- the president has an opinion that we should pull our troops out of Syria. You're right. They're going to be still in the region. We're still going to be there. I think that the press overreacts to everything the president does, and they did to this visit. I mean, the signing of the MAGA hats. Somebody came on, and the analysis was it's a violation of the Hatch Act. I mean, he's signing a MAGA hat. We know the guys like the hats. They want him to sign the hat. He used the word -- what was the word he used? "Suckers." America is no longer suckers. People overreacted to that. "Oh, how dare you call our troops suckers?" He wasn't calling the troops suckers. He was saying America -- it's a part of his "America first" philosophy. And he was saying we don't need our troops fighting at a disadvantage. So I think it's always -- it's always the overreaction. I don't think you do it, Marie Harf.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Thank you. I try not to. Because I do think people do. I think a lot of people, every little thing they blow out of proportion. I do think there were legitimate things to criticize on this visit. And his language matters. Right? His language has consequences.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Did the suckers bother you?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: It's not the worst thing I've ever heard him say, but I didn't like it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But what put us in danger, that --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I don't -- I don't like when he's asked, "Were you nervous about coming to a war zone," and he made it all about how nervous he was about the danger, right?

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But wasn't that real, though? I mean, the president had never been there before. The shades are down.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Which is a -- which is a problem.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: This is the first time there.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: And he had his wife. And he had his wife.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Which is a problem that he hasn't been there before.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And I think the fact that he was dishonest --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Why is it a problem?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I think the fact that he was dishonest with the troops about pay raises, I really don't like that. For some reason, that just -- it's a fact. He said it wrong.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: But why does it bother you that he talked about him being afraid going into a war zone? I mean, that's real.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: He should talk about their sacrifice and not his.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Look, I think he knows --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: If I were his communications advisor, that's what I would advise him. I'm not.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: I think a lot of people -- a lot of people are more concerned --

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: I'm not making a civil case out of it.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: -- about what the military feels about it. But when I watch those military men and women being so excited, I think we should just leave it up to them.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: And some military folks have been on TV in the past few days criticizing it. There's members of the military on all political sides of the aisle here. So --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: That's fair.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: -- we should just --

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: We've got to go.

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: -- remember that.

utterances.speaker: JONES
utterances.utterance: Up next, we're putting our trivia knowledge to the test when FOX Nation's "The Quiz Show" comes back, all on "The Five." Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: I hope my fellow "Fivers" are ready to test their knowledge of fun facts, like I do every weekday at 7 p.m. on "The Quiz Show," only on FOX Nation. All right. Let's get started. Do you have your --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Got it.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: -- your A, B -- your A's, your B's and your C's, right?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Ready.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Here we go. Question No. 1: "What did Jeff Bezos originally want to name Amazon?" Was it: A, Netmart; B, Homespun; or C, Cadabra?

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Can you say them again?

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: We can't --

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Hold it towards me, Lawrence.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm going to guess this.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Amazon originally, Netmart, Homespun or Cadabra? And you've got your answers. The answer is Cadabra, "C."

utterances.speaker: HARF
utterances.utterance: Woo!

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Marie Harf with a "C." Cadabra, that's right. Netmart sounds like it could be an Amazon rival, right? Homespun seems like a nice, warm, fuzzy name. But it was Cadabra, as in abracadabra. They originally wanted to name it.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, I'm glad he went with Amazon.

utterances.speaker: ORTAGUS
utterances.utterance: Yes, sounds like --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I would not want to be a Cadabra prime member.

utterances.speaker: SHILLUE
utterances.utterance: Question No. 2, "What type of animal babies are called kits? The males are called hobs, and the females are called jills? Is this guinea pigs, ferrets or hedgehogs?
